title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that law enforcement officers face increasing risks in the war against drugs and crime, with a rise in violent crime and drug use. Many individuals arrested also test positive for drug usage. The Federal Government provides support for law enforcement officers who are on the front line in the war against drugs and crime. The rate of violent crime is increasing along with drug use, and a large percentage of individuals arrested test positive for drug usage. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 highlighted various issues affecting law enforcement, and a review twenty-five years later would help evaluate current problems, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 highlighted issues affecting law enforcement. A review twenty-five years later would evaluate current problems, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would help redefine relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. A national commission called the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established. The Commission's duties are outlined. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies and issues at the Federal, State, and local levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, and research/training status. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will study the effectiveness of information-sharing systems, research and training status, adequacy of equipment and resources, cooperation among law enforcement agencies, and the responsibility of governments in solving the crime problem. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will assess equipment, resources, cooperation among law enforcement agencies, responsibility of governments in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. They will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will assess the impact of the criminal justice system on law enforcement, including court schedules and prison overcrowding. They will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information and advice on important law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations appointed by various leaders in Congress and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members, with appointments made by leaders in Congress and the President. Appointments include individuals from national law enforcement organizations, with specific numbers appointed by different leaders. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. Seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations are appointed by different leaders, including the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. Seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations are appointed by different leaders, including the President. Additionally, academic experts on law enforcement issues are appointed by various leaders in Congress. The Commission includes two academic experts on law enforcement issues appointed by leaders in Congress. The Commission includes members appointed by leaders in Congress, the President, and individuals from Federal law enforcement agencies. The Commission includes members appointed by leaders in Congress, the President, and individuals from Federal law enforcement agencies. The members consist of the Majority Leader and Minority Leader of the Senate, individuals from the Department of the Treasury and Department of Justice appointed by the President, and individuals representing State or local governmental entities appointed by the Senate Majority Leader and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Commission includes members appointed by leaders in Congress, the President, and individuals from Federal law enforcement agencies. The members consist of individuals representing State or local governmental entities appointed by the Senate Majority Leader, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and the President. The Comptroller General shall oversee the methodology and approach of the Commission's study. The Commission members include representatives appointed by Congress, the President, and State or local governmental entities. The Comptroller General oversees the study methodology. Members receive no additional compensation for their service. The Commission members, appointed by various entities, select a chairperson upon appointment. They receive no extra compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate actions to members or agents, obtain information from federal agencies, and accept gifts and donations. The Commission is authorized to obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts and donations, and use the United States mails. The Commission will submit a report with legislative proposals to Congress within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. Upon submitting its report, the Commission will cease to exist after sixty days. Title XXXIV of the Crime Control Act of 1990 and title II, section 211 B of the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1991 will be repealed.
